\title{On the divisibility of the class numbers and discriminants of imaginary quadratic fields}
\author{Meng Fai Lim\footnote{School of Mathematics and Statistics $\&$ Hubei Key Laboratory of Mathematical Sciences,
Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430079, P.R.China. E-mail:
\texttt{limmf@mail.ccnu.edu.cn}}}
\date{}
\maketitle

\begin{abstract} \footnotesize
\noindent
 Let $n$ be a squarefree positive odd integer. We will show that
there exist infinitely many imaginary quadratic number fields with
discriminant divisible by $n$ and$-$at the same time$-$having an
element of order $n$ in the class group. We will also prove certain
results on the divisibility of $r(N)$, where $r(N)$ is the
representation numbers of $N$ as sums of three squares. Namely, we
will show that for a given squarefree positive odd integer $n$ there
exist infinitely many $N$ such that $n$ divides both $N$ and $r(N)$.

\medskip
\noindent Keywords and Phrases: Class group, discriminant, sums of
three squares.

\smallskip
\noindent Mathematics Subject Classification 2010: 11R11, 11R29,
11R70.

\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
The class group of a number field is certainly one of the most
important arithmetic objects in number theory. Even in the case of
an imaginary quadratic field there is a great amount of research on
the divisibility of the class number. In particular, for a given
positive integer $n>1$, it was shown by many authors that there
exist infinitely many imaginary quadratic number fields each with
class number divisible by $n$ (see \cite{AC, BL, Cho, GR, Hum1,
Hum2, Ki08, Ki09, Ki10a, Ki10b, Kur, Lou, Mo, Na, S, Ue}). It is
interesting to note that in all the above cited works, they do not
seem to keep track of the dependence of $n$ on other arithmetic
invariants of the quadratic extensions (except maybe \cite{BL} to a
certain extent). In fact, in \cite{B}, Byeon raised the following
problem, which is formulated rather vaguely.

\medskip \noindent \textbf{Problem.} \cite{B} Let $S$ be an ``interesting'' infinite
set of number fields and $p$ a prime. Are there infinitely many
number fields $K$ in $S$, whose class number $h(K)$ is divisible by
$p$ (or not divisible by $p$)?

\medskip
In this paper, we are considering a class $S$ of imaginary quadratic
fields of a certain type, which we now describe. Let $n$ be a
squarefree odd integer $>1$. Let $S$ be the class of imaginary
quadratic number fields, whose discriminant is divisible by $n$. We
will investigate the question, whether there are infinitely many
number fields $K$ in $S$ whose class number $h(K)$ is divisible by
$n$. Therefore, our investigation can be viewed as considering the
divisibility of the class numbers under the constraint of the
divisibility of the discriminants. Our results will be presented in
the next theorem, where the description of $S$ is more explicit.

\begin{thm} \label{main1}
 Let $n$ be a squarefree odd integer $>1$.  Then the following
statements are valid.

\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(1)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d<0$
such that $d\equiv 5$ mod 8, $d$ is divisible by $n$ and such that
the class group of the imaginary quadratic number field
${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ contains an element of order $n$.

\item[$(1')$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d<0$
such that $d\equiv 1$ mod 8, $d$ is divisible by $n$ and such that
the class group of the imaginary quadratic number field
${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ contains an element of order $n$.


\item[$(2)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d<0$
such that $d\equiv 2$ mod 4, $d$ is divisible by $n$ and such that
the class group of the imaginary quadratic number field
${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ contains an element of order $n$.

\item[$(3)$]There exist infinitely many squarefree $d<0$
such that $d\equiv 3$ mod 4, $d$ is divisible by $n$ and such that
the class group of the imaginary quadratic number field
${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ contains an element of order $n$.
 \end{enumerate}
In particular, in each congruence class $5$ mod 8, $1$ mod 8, $2$ mod 4 and 3 mod 4, there exist infinitely squarefree integers $d<0$ such that 
$\mathrm{gcd}(d, h(d))$ is divisible by $n$. Here $h(d)$ is the class number of ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$.
\end{thm}

































\begin{remark}

applying the theorem to prove Corollary \ref{mainsum1} and Theorem
\ref{mainreal}, we have labeled our statements in such a fashion
corresponding to their application to the respective statements in
Corollary \ref{mainsum1} and Theorem \ref{mainreal}. \end{remark}


 \begin{remark}
 The squarefree condition on $n$ is imposed by our requirement that $n$ divides the
 discriminant of the imaginary quadratic number field which is in
 turn squarefree (up to a power of 2). A slightly weaker version of Theorem \ref{main1}
 is also
 proven in \cite{Lim}.
\end{remark}

number of representations of $N$ as a sum of 3 squares. A classical
theorem of Gauss (for instance, see \cite[Chap. 4 \S 8]{Gro})
asserts that

  We can now
state the following corollary which is concerned with the
divisibility of $\mathrm{gcd}(n, r(N))$.

 \begin{cor} \label{mainsum1}
 Let $n$ be a squarefree odd integer $>1$. Then the following
statements are valid.

\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(1)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $N$
such that $N\equiv 3$ mod 8, $N$ is divisible by $n$ and $r(N)$ is
divisible by $24n$.

\item[$(2)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $N$
such that $N\equiv 2$ mod 4, $N$ is divisible by $n$ and $r(N)$ is
divisible by $12n$.

\item[$(3)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $N$
such that $N\equiv 1$ mod 4, $N$ is divisible by $n$ and $r(N)$ is
divisible by $12n$.
 \end{enumerate}

 In particular, in each congruence class $3$ mod 8, $2$ mod 4 and 1 mod 4, there exist infinitely squarefree integers $N$ such that $\mathrm{gcd}(N, r(N))$ is divisible by $n$.
\end{cor}

\begin{remark} in \cite[Theorem 2]{Cho}, Cho has also established the infinitude of $N$ in
certain arithmetic progressions whose $r(N)$ is divisible by $n$. However, his results do not have the constraint on the divisibility of $N$.
Our result may therefore be viewed as complement to the results there.   \end{remark}









































It would be of interest to establish results analogous to that in
Theorem \ref{main1} for the real quadratic fields. At present, we
can only prove results in this direction for the 3-rank of the ideal
class groups. Notice that unlike the imaginary situation, our
results in the real situation obtain a family of real quadratic
fields whose discriminant is \textit{not} divisible by $3$.

\begin{thm} \label{mainreal}
 Let $n$ be a squarefree odd integer $>1$ which is coprime to 3.
 Then there exist infinitely many real quadratic number fields $F$ which
satisfy all the following properties.

\begin{enumerate}
\item[$(1)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d>0$
such that $d\equiv 1$ mod 8, $d$ is divisible by $n$ but not
divisible by $3$, and such that the 3-rank of the class group of the
imaginary number field ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ is at least 2.

\item[$(2)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d>0$
such that $d\equiv 2$ mod 4, $d$ is divisible by $n$ but not
divisible by $3$, and such that the 3-rank of the class group of the
imaginary number field ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ is at least 2.

\item[$(3)$] There exist infinitely many squarefree $d>0$
such that $d\equiv 3$ mod 4, $d$ is divisible by $n$ but not
divisible by $3$, and such that the 3-rank of the class group of the
imaginary number field ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ is at least 2.
 \end{enumerate}  \end{thm}

\section{A result of Karoubi and Lambre}

We now state the following result of Karoubi and Lambre
\cite[Proposition 2.8]{KL}, which our results will depend on. For
the proof which relies on an algebraic $K$-theory argument, we refer
to the original paper (see also \cite{KL2} or \cite{Lim}).

\begin{thm} \label{KL1}
 Let $K$ be an imaginary quadratic field with discriminant $D$. Let
 $n$ be an odd divisor of $D$. Suppose that there exist triples $(a, b, c)\in
 {\mathds{Z}}^3$ satisfying all of the following properties$:$
 \begin{enumerate}
\item[$(i)$] $(a, b) = (c, n) =1$.

\item[$(ii)$] $b\neq \pm 1$.

\item[$(iii)$] $a^2 - 4b^n = c^2D.$
 \end{enumerate}
Then the class group of $K$ contains an element of order $n$. \end{thm}

Finally, we shall prove Theorem \ref{mainreal}.

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem \ref{mainreal}]
 Let $n= 3$. By Theorem \ref{main1}, there exists infinitely many $K= {\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d'})$ with $d'\equiv 5$ mod 8 such that

latter implies the 3-rank of the ideal class group of the real
quadratic field ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ is at least 2, where $d:=-d'/3$. It
remains to show that $d \equiv 1$ mod 8. Note that since $d'=5$ mod
8 and $3\mid d'$, we have $d' \equiv 21$ mod 24. This in turn gives
the required congruence. The discriminant of ${\mathds{Q}}(\sqrt{d})$ is
precisely $d=-d'/3$ which is not divisible by 3. The proofs of the
remaining cases are similar.\end{proof}
